Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to amounts specified in a 1992 agreement, with any additional amounts subject to the agreement's requirements. The special representatives of the Governor of the Northern Mariana Islands are subject to the requirements of an agreement, with additional amounts available in each fiscal year. The additional amounts are to be used for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa for fiscal year 1996, and for Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Republic of thereafter. For fiscal years 1997 and beyond, funds are designated for capital infrastructure projects in Guam, the Virgin Islands, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Republic of Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of the Marshall Islands. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million is allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas, with up to $3 million annually for immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary of the Interior allocates funds for infrastructure projects in the Northern Mariana Islands to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues. Projects are outlined in a five-year plan developed in consultation with island governments and updated annually. The plan prioritizes projects and considers overall master plans and Corps of Engineers reviews. The Secretary prioritizes infrastructure projects in the Northern Mariana Islands based on a five-year plan, considering master plans, Corps of Engineers reviews, maintenance needs, local cost-share requirements, and proposing an emergency fund for natural disasters. The text chunk discusses the allocation of funds for an emergency fund without fiscal year limitation, not exceeding $10 million, to assist in the repair, replacement, or hardening of essential facilities in the event of disasters. Additionally, it mentions additional contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll, capped at $32 million, contingent upon a satisfactory agreement with the President. The allocation of funds for resettlement of Rongelap Atoll after January 1, 1995 is capped at $32 million, contingent upon a satisfactory agreement with the President for full settlement of obligations. Federal agencies in the Republic of the Marshall Islands are authorized to provide timely assistance through the Secretary of the Interior for resettlement activities. The provision of ex gratia assistance for individuals at Rongelap is not limited by this subsection, except that assistance cannot be provided until all funds necessary for resettlement have been provided. SEC. 2. FEDERAL MINIMUM WAGE. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, starting at $2.75 per hour and increasing annually. Effective January 1, 1997, the minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be raised by thirty cents per hour annually until it reaches the wage rate set forth in section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Once it reaches that rate, the minimum wage will be set at the same level as specified in the Act. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, along with other government officials, must submit a report to Congress by March 15 each year detailing the use of funds allocated for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities. The report includes immigration data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI. The report to Congress must include information on the treatment of non-US citizen contract workers in the Northern Mariana Islands, the impact of local laws on Federal interests, the condition of detention facilities, the accuracy of the alien identification system, and reasons for ineffective enforcement of Federal laws. The report to Congress must include details on the alien identification and tracking system's compatibility with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, as well as reasons for ineffective enforcement of Federal laws in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands without funding from the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. IMMIGRATION COOPERATION. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will work together to identify and potentially exclude or deport individuals posing security or law enforcement risks to the Commonwealth or the United States. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF LOCAL EMPLOYMENT IN THE MARIANAS. The amendment allows aliens in the CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on vessels operating within the CNMI waters and US exclusive economic zone. They are considered employed in the US and have permission from the Attorney General to accept such employment. Aliens in the CNMI can work as unlicensed seamen on vessels in CNMI waters and US exclusive economic zone. They are considered employed in the US and have permission from the Attorney General to accept such employment. Amendments to title 46 of the United States Code are made regarding employment provisions for aliens in the CNMI. Ownership of submerged lands in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands clarified. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections. References to enactment dates in the law now refer to the date of enactment of this specific section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress on the economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management of various US territories and Pacific island nations. Additionally, a technical correction is made to include the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in certain sections of Public Law 93-435. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to include the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia. Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
